verse: There is an evil that I have seen under the sun, a common burden that people bear:

God gives somebody wealth, riches, and honor, so that he lacks nothing of everything that he craves, but God does not give him the opportunity to eat it. Instead, a stranger eats it. This is vapor, and a sickening evil.

A man may father a hundred children and live many years, but if his soul is not satisfied with good things and he does not even have a proper burial, no matter how many days he lives, I say, “A stillborn baby is better off than he is.”
Why? Because that baby comes like a vapor and leaves in darkness, and its name gets covered in darkness.
The baby does not see the sun or know it, but it enjoys more peaceful rest than that man does,
even if that man would live a thousand years two times without enjoying good things. They all go to the same place, don’t they?
All of a man’s hard work is to feed his mouth, but his appetite never feels satisfied.
So what advantage does a wise man have over a fool? What advantage does a poor man gain, who knows how to keep walking among the living?
Better to have eyes that look at what is actually there than desires that roam. This too is vapor and chasing the wind.
Whatever exists already has its name, and it is already known what man is. He is not able to win in court against one who is stronger than he is.
Yes, the more words, the more vapor. What advantage does a man have?
For who knows what is good for a man in life, in the few days of his life, that vanishes like vapor, that passes like a shadow? Who will tell the man what will be after him, under the sun?
